thread.title: Theresa May vows to stay on despite humbling hung parliament result

author: Mike Kelly
title: Theresa May vows to stay on despite humbling hung parliament result
text:
News Theresa May vows to stay on despite humbling hung parliament result Knives appeared to be out for Tory leader Theresa May but colleagues are beginning to rally around her Share British Prime Minister Theresa May leaves Conservative Party Headquaters (Photo: Getty Images Europe) Share Get daily updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email 
Prime Minister Theresa May has vowed to stay on, it has emerged. 
There were suggestions she might stand down after her snap general election gamble backfired spectacularly resulting in a hung parliament . 
However, BBC political editor Laura Kuenssberg tweeted: “PM has no intention of resigning - working to form a govt based on being largest party in seats and votes.” 
And, after the initial shock and anger in some circles, other Tory colleagues began to rally around their beleaguered leader. 
ITV’s political editor Robert Peston said ministers had told him they were urging her not to, citing her 43% share of vote, up from David Cameron’s 36% in 2015. 
And it equals the figure enjoyed by Tony Blair in the 1997 general election. 
But it has been a damaging experience for the Prime Minister who has been strongly criticised for her campaign. 
And, if she does try to tough it out, she will be constantly reminded that she wanted more seats to give her more authority in Brexit negotiations. Instead the party lost its 17-seat majority. Read More General Election 2017 North East results in full: How North East constituencies voted 
Conservative MP Nigel Evans says the election result has been an “absolute disaster” for the Conservatives, claiming the campaign was “hijacked by (his) own party”. 
Evans, who retained his seat in the Ribble Valley, said the Conservative party “did a full-frontal assault on our core voters - the elderly”. 
He told BBC Radio 5 live’s Nicky Campbell: “We didn’t shoot ourselves in the foot, we shot ourselves in the head.” 
How long Mrs May stays on will depend on the amount of Tory MPs happy to keep backing her. 
UK Election 2017 results LIVE: Theresa May expected to cling on in hung parliament 
In effect she needs the support of every single one of them as she could end up forming a minority government or having a the slimmest of majorities through the support of the Democratic Unionists from Northern Ireland. 
It has been reported the likes of Boris Johnson and Philip Hammond have been invited to talk on the issue but have so far declined. 
So her future is still in doubt and the choice to stay could be taken out of her own hands. Read More
